title: Lymphadenitis
subject: Pathology
description: MCQs on lymphadenopathy, lymphadenitis, granulomatous inflammation, and reactive hyperplasia.

questions.questionText: What is lymphadenopathy?
options: Enlargement of lymph nodes due to disease
questions.correctAnswer: Enlargement of lymph nodes due to disease
questions.explanation: Lymphadenopathy refers to lymph node enlargement resulting from various pathological processes.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is an example of localized lymphadenopathy?
questions.explanation: Localized lymphadenopathy affects a specific group of nodes, such as cervical nodes in tonsillitis.

questions.questionText: Which disease is characterized by caseating granulomas?
questions.explanation: Tuberculosis classically presents with caseating granulomas in affected lymph nodes.

questions.questionText: What is the hallmark of sarcoidosis in lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Sarcoidosis typically presents with non-caseating granulomas without central necrosis.

questions.questionText: Which condition is associated with sinus histiocytosis?
questions.explanation: Sinus histiocytosis is commonly seen in lymph nodes draining cancers, due to increased macrophage activity.

questions.questionText: Which cells are predominantly increased in follicular hyperplasia?
questions.explanation: Follicular hyperplasia involves the proliferation of B cells in lymphoid follicles.

questions.questionText: Paracortical hyperplasia primarily involves which type of cells?
questions.explanation: Paracortical hyperplasia is characterized by T-cell proliferation in the paracortical zones.

questions.questionText: Which virus is responsible for infectious mononucleosis?
questions.explanation: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) causes infectious mononucleosis and is associated with atypical lymphocytes.

questions.questionText: Which feature is typical of acute bacterial lymphadenitis?
questions.explanation: Acute bacterial lymphadenitis presents with neutrophils and tissue congestion in the affected nodes.

questions.questionText: What is reactive lymphoid hyperplasia?
questions.explanation: Reactive lymphoid hyperplasia is a benign, non-neoplastic response to antigenic stimulation.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a cause of generalized lymphadenopathy?
questions.explanation: Infectious mononucleosis often causes generalized lymph node enlargement due to systemic viral infection.

questions.questionText: Which metabolic condition can rarely cause lymphadenopathy?
questions.explanation: Rare metabolic storage disorders like Gaucher disease can cause lymphadenopathy.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a primary neoplastic cause of lymphadenopathy?
questions.explanation: Lymphoma is a primary malignancy of the lymphoid tissue and a neoplastic cause of node enlargement.

questions.questionText: Which region is most commonly affected in mesenteric lymphadenitis?
questions.explanation: Mesenteric lymphadenitis involves abdominal lymph nodes, often seen in appendicitis.

questions.questionText: Which finding is seen in infectious mononucleosis blood smear?
questions.explanation: Atypical lymphocytes are a hallmark of infectious mononucleosis caused by EBV.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT a feature of acute viral lymphadenitis?
questions.explanation: Viral infections typically cause lymphocytic infiltration, not neutrophilic predominance.

questions.questionText: Chronic nonspecific lymphadenitis is most likely due to:
questions.explanation: Chronic nonspecific lymphadenitis results from prolonged antigenic stimulation, often due to chronic infections.

questions.questionText: Which of the following typically shows paracortical hyperplasia?
questions.explanation: Viral infections like infectious mononucleosis cause T-cell (paracortical) hyperplasia in nodes.

questions.questionText: Lymph node enlargement in cancer is usually due to:
questions.explanation: Secondary lymphadenopathy in cancer typically occurs due to metastatic deposits in the nodes.

questions.questionText: Which lymph node finding is common in nodes draining an area of cancer?
questions.explanation: Sinus histiocytosis reflects the immune systemâ€™s response to tumor antigens in draining lymph nodes.
